title: Psychology explains why people are a**holes.
description:
There's this thing in social psychology called the Actor-Observer Bias and it's basically where you assume the best in yourself and the worst in others. Everybody's doin' it.

The lesson here: Humans suck. Try to suck less. 

This is from the first episode of my new podcast—5 Harsh Truths That Changed My Life—which dropped on my channel today. 

Oh and welcome to The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F*ck Podcast. 

Do me a favor, check it out, leave a review and of course, subscribe. 🙂

transcription: If I run a red light, it's because I'm in a hurry and I have a really important meeting to get to, but if somebody else runs a red light, they are an evil, irresponsible asshole and they should never be able to drive again. I think moving away from that mindset and recognizing that our cognitive machinery is very flawed and everybody is constantly battling against those flaws, it opens you up to a lot more compassion. Everybody's starting from a pretty bad spot. Everybody has had monumental challenges throughout their lives. Everybody suffers from the same perceptual flaws, biases, corruptible memories that we do. And so maybe have a little bit of patience and grace with those people. Maybe when you see that guy go through the red light, don't think, wow, what a horrible asshole, how irresponsible. Maybe challenge yourself to think, hmm, maybe he has something really important going on. Maybe he's panicking right now.
